canonical_explanation.text: Simple machines make work easier by multiplying force or changing its direction. Mechanical Advantage (MA) is the ratio of load to effort. Velocity Ratio (VR) is the ratio of distance moved by effort to distance moved by load. Efficiency = (MA/VR) x 100%. Levers are classified into three classes based on the positions of fulcrum, load, and effort. Single fixed pulleys have VR = 1 and change direction only. Single movable pulleys have VR = 2. In inclined planes, VR = length/height. The screw and wedge are modifications of the inclined plane.
rules: Velocity Ratio VR = Distance by effort/Distance by load
For ideal machine: MA = VR, efficiency = 100%
Single fixed pulley: VR = 1, Single movable pulley: VR = 2

questions.question_text: Mechanical advantage is defined as:
questions.explanation_correct: The mechanical advantage (MA) is defined as the ratio of the load to the effort. This means that the MA is the number of times the machine multiplies the applied force to make the work easier.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mechanical advantage is not defined as effort divided by load, load times effort, or load plus effort. The correct definition is that MA is the ratio of load to effort, meaning how much the force is multiplied by the machine to make the work easier.

questions.question_text: Velocity ratio is defined as:

options.text: Distance moved by load / Distance moved by effort
Distance moved by effort / Distance moved by load
Speed of effort / Speed of load
Time for effort / Time for load

questions.explanation_correct: The velocity ratio is defined as the ratio of the distance moved by the effort to the distance moved by the load. This measures how much the simple machine multiplies the effort to move the load.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Velocity ratio is not the ratio of the speed of the effort to the speed of the load, nor the ratio of the time for the effort to the time for the load. It is specifically the ratio of the distance moved by the effort to the distance moved by the load, which shows how the machine multiplies the effort.

questions.question_text: Efficiency of a machine is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: The efficiency of a machine is given by the formula (Mechanical Advantage/Velocity Ratio) x 100%. This is because the efficiency measures how well the machine uses the input effort to do the desired work, and this is best represented by the ratio of Mechanical Advantage to Velocity Ratio.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct option is B, (MA/VR) x 100%. This is because the efficiency of a machine is a measure of how effectively it uses the input effort to do the desired work. The Mechanical Advantage (MA) represents the force multiplication, while the Velocity Ratio (VR) represents the speed/distance trade-off. The efficiency is therefore best represented by the ratio of these two quantities, multiplied by 100 to get a percentage.

questions.question_text: For an ideal machine:
questions.explanation_correct: For an ideal machine, the mechanical advantage (MA) is equal to the velocity ratio (VR). This means that the ratio of the load to the effort is the same as the ratio of the distance moved by the effort to the distance moved by the load.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (MA > VR) is incorrect because in an ideal machine, the mechanical advantage and velocity ratio are equal. Option B (MA < VR) is incorrect because this would mean the machine is not ideal. Option D (MA = 0) is incorrect because this would mean the machine is not doing any work at all.

questions.question_text: In a first-class lever, the fulcrum is:

options.text: At one end with load at other end

questions.explanation_correct: In a first-class lever, the fulcrum is located between the load and the effort, which allows the effort to be multiplied to move the load. This arrangement gives the lever a mechanical advantage greater than 1, making work easier.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a first-class lever, the fulcrum is located between the load and the effort. This position allows the effort to be multiplied to move the load, giving the lever a mechanical advantage greater than 1. The other options, such as the fulcrum being at one end with the load at the other end, or the fulcrum being at the load end, do not represent the defining characteristic of a first-class lever.

questions.question_text: In a second-class lever, the load is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a second-class lever, the load is positioned between the fulcrum and the effort. This arrangement allows the lever to multiply the effort force, making work easier.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The load in a second-class lever is not at one end, at the fulcrum, or above the effort. Instead, it is positioned between the fulcrum and the effort. This lever setup is designed to increase the force or effort applied, making the work easier to do.

questions.question_text: An example of a third-class lever is:
questions.explanation_correct: A fishing rod is an example of a third-class lever, where the fulcrum (the hand holding the rod) is between the effort (the hand pulling the line) and the load (the fish at the end of the line). This type of lever amplifies the speed or motion of the effort applied, making it easier to reel in the fish.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not examples of third-class levers. A nutcracker is a first-class lever, with the fulcrum between the effort and the load. A see-saw is a first-class lever, with the fulcrum in the middle. A wheelbarrow is a second-class lever, with the load between the fulcrum (the wheel) and the effort (the hands pushing).

questions.question_text: A single fixed pulley has a velocity ratio of:
questions.explanation_correct: A single fixed pulley has a velocity ratio of 1 because the distance moved by the effort is the same as the distance moved by the load. This is because the pulley only changes the direction of the force, not its magnitude.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The velocity ratio of a single fixed pulley is not 0, 2, or 0.5. A single fixed pulley has a velocity ratio of 1 because the distance moved by the effort is the same as the distance moved by the load. This is because the pulley only changes the direction of the force, not its magnitude.

questions.question_text: A single movable pulley has a velocity ratio of:
questions.explanation_correct: A single movable pulley has a velocity ratio (VR) of 2. This is because the load is lifted half the distance that the effort moves, so the VR is 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is C) 2. A single movable pulley has a VR of 2 because the load is lifted half the distance that the effort moves. Option A) 0.5 is incorrect because that would mean the load is lifted twice the distance of the effort, which is not the case for a single movable pulley. Options B) 1 and D) 3 are also incorrect because they do not match the actual VR of a single movable pulley.

questions.question_text: For an inclined plane, VR equals:
questions.explanation_correct: The velocity ratio (VR) of an inclined plane is defined as the ratio of the distance moved by the effort to the distance moved by the load. Since the effort moves along the length of the inclined plane and the load moves along the height, the VR is equal to the length divided by the height.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The VR of an inclined plane is not equal to the height divided by the length, the height multiplied by the length, or the height plus the length. The VR is specifically the ratio of the length to the height, as the effort moves along the length while the load moves along the height of the inclined plane.

questions.question_text: A lever has effort arm 50 cm and load arm 10 cm. Its MA is:
questions.explanation_correct: The mechanical advantage (MA) of a lever is the ratio of the length of the effort arm to the length of the load arm. Since the effort arm is 50 cm and the load arm is 10 cm, the MA is 50/10 = 5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer A) 0.2 is wrong because it would mean the effort arm is 5 times shorter than the load arm, which is not the case here. The incorrect answer C) 60 is wrong because it does not represent the ratio of the effort arm to the load arm. The incorrect answer D) 40 is wrong because it does not match the correct MA calculation of 5.

questions.question_text: A machine lifts a load of 200 N with an effort of 50 N. The MA is:
questions.explanation_correct: The mechanical advantage (MA) is the ratio of load to effort. Since the load is 200 N and the effort is 50 N, the MA is 200 N / 50 N = 4, which is option B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mechanical advantage (MA) is the ratio of load to effort. Option A (0.25) is the reciprocal of the correct answer, which would mean the effort is 4 times the load, not the other way around. Option C (250) and D (150) are incorrect because they do not represent the ratio of load to effort.

questions.question_text: A machine has MA = 4 and VR = 5. Its efficiency is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 80%. Efficiency = (MA/VR) x 100%, so for a machine with MA = 4 and VR = 5, the efficiency would be (4/5) x 100% = 80%.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) 80%. Option B) 125% is incorrect because efficiency cannot be greater than 100%. Option C) 20% is incorrect because the formula for efficiency gives a higher value. Option D) 9% is incorrect because the efficiency calculation does not result in this value.

questions.question_text: An inclined plane is 10 m long and 2 m high. Its VR is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 5. The velocity ratio (VR) of an inclined plane is equal to the length of the inclined plane divided by its height. In this case, the inclined plane is 10 m long and 2 m high, so the VR is 10/2 = 5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not accurately represent the velocity ratio of the inclined plane. Option A) 0.2 is the inverse of the correct answer, which is not the velocity ratio. Options C) 20 and D) 12 do not match the calculation of the length divided by the height of the inclined plane.

questions.question_text: A block and tackle system has 4 pulleys. Its VR is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a block and tackle system with 4 pulleys, the Velocity Ratio (VR) is 4. This is because each movable pulley doubles the VR, and with 4 pulleys, the VR becomes 2^4 = 16.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not match the VR for a block and tackle system with 4 pulleys. Option A (VR = 2) is for a single movable pulley, while options C (VR = 8) and D (VR = 16) are incorrect because the VR for 4 pulleys is 16, not 8 or 16.

questions.question_text: A wheelbarrow is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: A wheelbarrow is an example of a second-class lever because the fulcrum (the wheel) is between the load (the object being carried) and the effort (the person pushing the wheelbarrow).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A wheelbarrow is not a first-class lever because the fulcrum is not between the load and the effort. It is also not a third-class lever because the effort is not between the fulcrum and the load. The correct answer is that a wheelbarrow is a second-class lever.

questions.question_text: The main advantage of a single fixed pulley is:
questions.explanation_correct: The main advantage of a single fixed pulley is that it changes the direction of the effort force. By changing the direction, it becomes easier to lift a heavy load using less effort.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A single fixed pulley does not multiply the force. It simply changes the direction of the effort force, making it easier to lift a heavy load. It also does not reduce friction or increase the speed - the velocity ratio of a single fixed pulley is 1, meaning the effort and load move the same distance.

questions.question_text: In an effort of 100 N moves down by 5 m and load of 400 N moves up by 1 m. The efficiency is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 80%. The efficiency of a simple machine is given by the formula: Efficiency = (Mechanical Advantage/Velocity Ratio) x 100%. In this case, the Mechanical Advantage is 4 (load of 400 N / effort of 100 N) and the Velocity Ratio is 5 (distance moved by effort of 5 m / distance moved by load of 1 m). Plugging these values into the formula gives an efficiency of 80%.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not match the calculated efficiency. Option B) 100% is incorrect because the efficiency cannot be more than 100%. Option C) 125% is incorrect because the efficiency cannot be more than 100%. Option D) 20% is incorrect because the calculated efficiency is 80%, not 20%.

questions.question_text: Scissors is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Scissors is an example of a first-class lever because the fulcrum (pivot point) is between the effort (your fingers) and the load (the blades).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Scissors is not an example of a second-class or third-class lever because in those types of levers, the fulcrum is not between the effort and the load. Scissors also does not use an inclined plane - it is a simple machine that operates using the lever principle.

questions.question_text: A screw is a modification of:
questions.explanation_correct: The screw is a modification of the inclined plane. The inclined plane is a simple machine that makes work easier by providing a sloped surface to move an object up or down. The screw is a variation of the inclined plane, where the inclined surface is wrapped around a cylinder to create a spiral staircase-like structure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The screw is not a modification of a lever, pulley, or wheel and axle. These are other types of simple machines that work on different principles. The screw works by using an inclined plane wrapped around a cylinder, which allows it to lift heavy objects by applying a smaller force.

questions.question_text: Why is MA always less than VR in practice?

options.text: Due to friction and weight of moving parts

questions.explanation_correct: In practice, MA is always less than VR due to friction and the weight of the moving parts in the simple machine. This is because some of the effort applied is used to overcome these forces, reducing the force available to lift the load.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options B, C, and D are incorrect because they do not fully explain why MA is always less than VR in practice. Excess effort, heavy load, or small distance alone do not account for the difference between MA and VR. The correct explanation is that friction and the weight of the moving parts in the simple machine reduce the force available to lift the load, making MA less than VR.

questions.question_text: A lever is in equilibrium with 200 N load at 20 cm from fulcrum. What effort is needed at 80 cm from fulcrum?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 50 N. This is because the lever is in equilibrium, so the product of the load and its distance from the fulcrum is equal to the product of the effort and its distance from the fulcrum. Since the load is 200 N at 20 cm, the effort at 80 cm must be 50 N to balance the lever.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct because they do not satisfy the equilibrium condition for the lever. B) 100 N and C) 800 N are incorrect because they do not match the calculated effort of 50 N. D) 200 N is incorrect because it is equal to the load, not the effort required to balance the lever.

questions.question_text: In a pulley system, if effort moves down 4 m and load rises 1 m, the VR is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 4. In a pulley system, the Velocity Ratio (VR) is the ratio of the distance moved by the effort to the distance moved by the load. If the effort moves down 4 m and the load rises 1 m, the VR is 4, since the distance moved by the effort (4 m) is 4 times the distance moved by the load (1 m).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not represent the correct Velocity Ratio (VR) for the given situation. Option A) 0.25 is the inverse of the correct VR, which should be 4. Option C) 5 and D) 3 are not the correct VR, as they do not accurately represent the ratio of the distance moved by the effort to the distance moved by the load.

questions.question_text: In a third-class lever, the effort is:

options.text: At the end opposite to fulcrum

questions.explanation_correct: In a third-class lever, the effort is applied between the fulcrum and the load. This is because the effort needs to be applied closer to the load in order to move the load, as the third-class lever has a mechanical advantage less than 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A, where the effort is applied between the fulcrum and the load. This is because in a third-class lever, the load is between the fulcrum and the effort, unlike the first-class and second-class levers where the effort is between the fulcrum and the load. Options B, C, and D are incorrect as they do not represent the position of the effort in a third-class lever.

questions.question_text: MA has no unit because it is:
questions.explanation_correct: Mechanical Advantage (MA) is a ratio of the load to the effort force. Since it is a ratio of two quantities with the same units, it has no units.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is correct because Mechanical Advantage (MA) is a ratio of the load force to the effort force. Since it is a dimensionless ratio, it has no units. Option A is incorrect because MA is not necessarily small. Option C is incorrect because MA is not always greater than 1. Option D is incorrect because MA is not a measure of power.

questions.question_text: A wedge is a:
questions.explanation_correct: A wedge is a double inclined plane, formed by two inclined surfaces. This allows it to apply a large force over a small distance to split or lift objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The wedge is not a single inclined plane, a modified lever, or a type of pulley. It is a special type of simple machine formed by two inclined planes joined together. This allows the wedge to convert a small force applied over a large distance into a large force applied over a small distance, making it very useful for splitting or lifting objects.

questions.question_text: A machine has efficiency 75% and VR = 4. The MA is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 3. This is because the formula for efficiency is efficiency = (MA/VR) x 100%, and with an efficiency of 75% and a VR of 4, the MA can be calculated as MA = (VR x efficiency)/100 = (4 x 75)/100 = 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not match the formula for calculating mechanical advantage (MA) given the efficiency and velocity ratio (VR). The correct formula is MA = (VR x efficiency)/100, which gives the MA as 3 for an efficiency of 75% and VR of 4.

questions.question_text: In a combination of fixed and movable pulleys with 6 strings supporting the load, the VR is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a combination of fixed and movable pulleys with 6 strings supporting the load, the velocity ratio (VR) is 6 because the load is raised by the combined movement of all 6 strings, each of which moves twice the distance of the effort applied.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The velocity ratio (VR) is not 3, 12, or 2 in this case. With 6 strings supporting the load, the load is raised by the combined movement of all 6 strings, each of which moves twice the distance of the effort applied. Therefore, the total distance moved by the load is 6 times the distance moved by the effort, giving a VR of 6.

questions.question_text: The human forearm is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: The human forearm is an example of a third-class lever, where the effort (bicep muscle) is applied between the fulcrum (elbow joint) and the load (weight being lifted). This type of lever gives a smaller mechanical advantage but increases the speed of motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The human forearm is not an example of a first-class or second-class lever. In a first-class lever, the fulcrum is between the effort and the load. In a second-class lever, the load is between the fulcrum and the effort. The forearm is a third-class lever, where the effort is applied between the fulcrum and the load.

questions.question_text: A screw with pitch 2 mm is rotated with a handle of radius 14 cm. The VR is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 440. The velocity ratio (VR) of a screw is equal to the circumference of the handle divided by the pitch of the screw. With a handle radius of 14 cm and a pitch of 2 mm, the VR is approximately 2π × 14 cm / 0.2 cm = 440.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not correctly calculate the velocity ratio of the screw. Option A) 44 is too low, Option C) 88 is also incorrect, and Option D) 22 is too low as well. The key is to use the formula for velocity ratio of a screw, which is the circumference of the handle divided by the pitch of the screw.

questions.question_text: A machine with MA greater than 1 is called a force multiplier.
questions.explanation_correct: A machine with a Mechanical Advantage (MA) greater than 1 is called a force multiplier because it can multiply the applied force, making work easier. This is because the MA is the ratio of the load to the effort, and a MA greater than 1 means the load is greater than the effort needed to move it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A machine is not called a force multiplier just because its MA is greater than 1. The term 'force multiplier' refers to a machine that can multiply the applied force, making work easier. This is true only if the MA is greater than 1, which means the load is greater than the effort needed to move it.

questions.question_text: An ideal machine has 100% efficiency.
questions.explanation_correct: An ideal machine has 100% efficiency. This means that all the effort (input) energy is converted into useful work (output), with no energy lost to friction or other forms of waste. In real-world machines, some energy is always lost, so the efficiency is less than 100%.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A real machine can never have 100% efficiency. This is because some energy is always lost due to friction and other factors, even in the best-designed machines. Some of the input energy is wasted instead of being converted into useful work. Therefore, the efficiency of a real machine is always less than 100%.

questions.question_text: A see-saw is an example of a first-class lever.
questions.explanation_correct: A see-saw is an example of a first-class lever, where the fulcrum (the point the see-saw pivots on) is located between the load (the person sitting on one end) and the effort (the person pushing down on the other end). This arrangement allows the see-saw to multiply the force and make the work easier.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A see-saw is not an example of a second-class or third-class lever. In a second-class lever, the load is between the fulcrum and the effort, while in a third-class lever, the effort is between the fulcrum and the load. The see-saw, with the fulcrum in the middle, is a classic example of a first-class lever.

questions.question_text: A single fixed pulley has mechanical advantage greater than 1.
questions.explanation_correct: A single fixed pulley has a velocity ratio (VR) of 1, meaning the distance moved by the effort is the same as the distance moved by the load. Since the mechanical advantage (MA) is the ratio of load to effort, a single fixed pulley has an MA of 1, which is not greater than 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The misconception is that a single fixed pulley increases the mechanical advantage. However, this is not the case. A single fixed pulley only changes the direction of the force, but does not multiply the force. Its mechanical advantage is 1, meaning the load and effort are equal. Therefore, the statement 'A single fixed pulley has mechanical advantage greater than 1' is false.

questions.question_text: A longer and gentler inclined plane requires less effort to push a load up.
questions.explanation_correct: A longer and gentler inclined plane requires less effort to push a load up because the load has to move a greater distance to reach the same height, reducing the amount of force needed. This is due to the increased velocity ratio (VR) of the inclined plane, which is the ratio of the distance moved by the effort to the distance moved by the load.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the inclined plane is longer and gentler, it would seem like it would require more effort to push the load up. However, this is not the case. A longer and gentler inclined plane actually requires less effort to push the load up because the velocity ratio (VR) is higher, meaning the load has to move a greater distance to reach the same height. This reduced amount of force needed is due to the mechanical advantage (MA) of the inclined plane.

questions.question_text: In real machines, MA is always less than VR due to friction.
questions.explanation_correct: In real machines, mechanical advantage (MA) is always less than the velocity ratio (VR) due to the effects of friction. Friction causes some of the effort to be lost, reducing the actual load that can be lifted compared to the theoretical value given by the VR. This means the MA will be lower than the VR.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is a common misconception that MA and VR are always equal. However, in real machines, friction causes some of the effort to be lost, so the actual load that can be lifted is less than the theoretical value given by the VR. This means the MA will always be lower than the VR.

questions.question_text: In a second-class lever, MA is always greater than 1.
questions.explanation_correct: In a second-class lever, the fulcrum is between the load and the effort. This means the distance between the fulcrum and the effort is greater than the distance between the fulcrum and the load. This gives a mechanical advantage (MA) greater than 1, as the effort applied is multiplied to move the load.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect. In a second-class lever, the fulcrum is between the load and the effort. This means the distance between the fulcrum and the effort is greater than the distance between the fulcrum and the load. This gives a mechanical advantage (MA) greater than 1, as the effort applied is multiplied to move the load. So, the MA is always greater than 1 in a second-class lever.

questions.question_text: Adding more pulleys to a system always increases both VR and efficiency.
questions.explanation_correct: Adding more pulleys to a system increases the Velocity Ratio (VR), but not necessarily the efficiency. Efficiency depends on the ratio of Mechanical Advantage (MA) to VR. Adding more pulleys can increase VR, but it may not increase MA proportionally, so the efficiency may not increase.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect because adding more pulleys increases the Velocity Ratio (VR) of the system, but it does not always increase the efficiency. Efficiency is the ratio of Mechanical Advantage (MA) to VR. Increasing the number of pulleys can increase the VR, but it may not increase the MA by the same factor, so the efficiency could actually decrease.

questions.question_text: A machine can never multiply work or energy.
questions.explanation_correct: A machine can indeed multiply work or energy. Simple machines like levers, pulleys, and inclined planes use mechanical advantage to increase the force applied, allowing the user to do more work with less effort.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is a common misconception that machines cannot multiply work or energy. However, this is not true. Simple machines use principles of mechanical advantage to multiply the force applied, allowing the user to do more work with less effort. For example, a lever can multiply the input force, and a pulley can change the direction of the applied force.

questions.question_text: In a third-class lever, the MA is always less than 1.
questions.explanation_correct: In a third-class lever, the fulcrum is between the effort and the load. This means the effort is applied between the fulcrum and the load. As a result, the Mechanical Advantage (MA) is always less than 1, which means the effort applied is greater than the load being moved.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. In a third-class lever, the fulcrum is between the effort and the load. This means the effort is applied between the fulcrum and the load. As a result, the Mechanical Advantage (MA) is always less than 1, which means the effort applied is greater than the load being moved. The MA being less than 1 does not mean the lever is inefficient, it just means more effort is required to move the load.

questions.question_text: Mechanical advantage equals load divided by ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The mechanical advantage (MA) of a simple machine is defined as the ratio of the load to the effort (or input force) needed to move that load. So, the correct answer is that MA equals the load divided by the effort.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be 'distance'. Mechanical advantage is not the ratio of the load to the distance moved by the load. Instead, it is the ratio of the load to the effort (or input force) needed to move that load. The correct answer is 'effort'.

questions.question_text: VR stands for ___ ratio.
questions.explanation_correct: VR stands for velocity ratio, which is the ratio of the distance moved by the effort (input) to the distance moved by the load (output). This tells us how much the machine can increase the speed or distance of the load compared to the effort applied.
questions.explanation_incorrect: VR does not stand for 'value ratio' or 'variable ratio'. The correct answer is 'velocity ratio', which measures how much the machine can increase the speed or distance of the load compared to the effort applied. The velocity ratio is a key property of simple machines that helps determine how much work they can do.

questions.question_text: Efficiency of a machine is always ___ than or equal to 100%.
questions.explanation_correct: The efficiency of a machine is always less than or equal to 100% because some energy is always lost to friction and other forms of energy waste. No machine can be 100% efficient in converting the input energy to useful work.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The efficiency of a machine cannot be greater than 100%. Efficiency is the ratio of the output work to the input work, so it can never exceed 100%. The accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is 'less'.

questions.question_text: The fixed point about which a lever turns is called the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The fixed point about which a lever turns is called the fulcrum. The fulcrum is the point where the lever rests and pivots, allowing the lever to move and change the direction of the force applied.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'fulcrum'. The fulcrum is the fixed point that the lever rotates around. This allows the lever to change the direction and magnitude of the force applied. The other options, such as 'load' or 'effort', do not refer to the fixed point of rotation for the lever.

questions.question_text: A single fixed pulley has VR equal to ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A single fixed pulley has a Velocity Ratio (VR) of 1 because the distance moved by the effort is the same as the distance moved by the load. This is because the fixed pulley only changes the direction of the force, but does not multiply the force applied.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 1. A single fixed pulley has a Velocity Ratio (VR) of 1, meaning the distance moved by the effort is the same as the distance moved by the load. This is because the fixed pulley only changes the direction of the force, but does not multiply the force applied. It is not 2 or any other number.

questions.question_text: In a lever, MA = effort arm divided by ___ arm.
questions.explanation_correct: The mechanical advantage (MA) of a lever is the ratio of the effort arm to the load arm. This means that the MA is calculated by dividing the effort arm by the load arm, so the correct answer is 'load'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to divide the effort arm by the effort arm. This is not correct because the mechanical advantage is calculated by dividing the effort arm by the load arm, not by the effort arm. The correct answer format is 'load'.

questions.question_text: For an inclined plane, VR = length divided by ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The velocity ratio (VR) of an inclined plane is the ratio of the distance moved by the effort to the distance moved by the load. Since the load moves a shorter distance than the effort, the VR is the ratio of the length of the inclined plane to its height.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'height'. For an inclined plane, the velocity ratio (VR) is the ratio of the distance moved by the effort to the distance moved by the load. questions.question_text: For an ideal machine, MA equals ___.
questions.explanation_correct: For an ideal machine, the Mechanical Advantage (MA) is equal to the Velocity Ratio (VR). This is because in an ideal machine, there are no losses and the input energy is fully transformed into output energy. The ratio of the load force to the effort force (MA) is then equal to the ratio of the distance moved by the effort to the distance moved by the load (VR).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'VR'. The Mechanical Advantage (MA) is not equal to the Mechanical Advantage (MA) itself. Instead, MA is equal to the Velocity Ratio (VR) in an ideal machine. This is because in an ideal machine, the input energy is fully transformed into output energy, so the ratio of load force to effort force (MA) is the same as the ratio of distance moved by effort to distance moved by load (VR).

questions.question_text: In a block and tackle system, VR equals the number of ___ supporting the load.
questions.explanation_correct: In a block and tackle system, the number of strings supporting the load determines the velocity ratio (VR). This is because the load is divided equally among the supporting strings, so the effort force is multiplied by the number of strings.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be something other than 'strings', such as 'pulleys'. This is not correct because the velocity ratio in a block and tackle system is determined by the number of strings supporting the load, not the number of pulleys. The correct answer is 'strings'.

questions.question_text: A screw is an inclined plane wrapped around a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A screw is an inclined plane wrapped around a cylinder. This allows the screw to convert a rotational motion into a linear motion, making it easier to lift or move heavy loads.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'cylinder'. A screw is not a flat inclined plane, but rather an inclined plane that is wrapped around a cylindrical surface. This cylindrical surface is what gives the screw its unique mechanical advantage and allows it to be used to lift or move heavy loads with relatively little effort.

questions.question_text: A nutcracker is an example of a ___-class lever.
questions.explanation_correct: A nutcracker is an example of a second-class lever because the fulcrum is between the load (the nut) and the effort (the handle). This arrangement gives the nutcracker a mechanical advantage, making it easier to crack the nut.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'second'. The nutcracker is a second-class lever, not a first-class or third-class lever. In a second-class lever, the fulcrum is between the load and the effort, which gives it a mechanical advantage and makes the work easier to do.

questions.question_text: Efficiency = (MA/VR) x ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The efficiency of a simple machine is equal to the mechanical advantage divided by the velocity ratio, and then multiplied by 100. This shows how much of the input effort is converted into useful output work, which is an important measure of a machine's performance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The efficiency is not just a simple percentage, but is calculated by the formula (MA/VR) x 100%. The correct answer to fill in the blank is '100%', as this completes the formula to determine the overall efficiency of the simple machine.
